ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Novel behavior in the M–H and field cooled (FC) curves of the MnFe2O4 nanoparticles synthesized by the coprecipitation method

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: MnFe2O4 nanoparticles were prepared by a coprecipitation chemical method. The average size of the obtained nanoparticles was about 30 nm. The hysteresis measured at T=300 K clearly shows ferromagnetic order at room temperature while that measured at T=450 K shows superparamagnetic behavior. The difference in the magnetization curves in the field increasing cycle and field decreasing cycle at higher temperatures (450 K or higher) is very unusual. In this case, a hysteresis in magnetization in higher magnetic fields with an opening up of the magnetization curve was observed. In this work, the effect of temperature and time of application of the applied field on the magnetization behavior was studied.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The spinel oxides RFe2O4, where R is typically a transition metal (R=Mn,Co,Ni…), is a large group of materials with very interesting physical properties. These kinds of materials in the form of thin film are used for spin filtering [1] and high magnetic storage [2]. In the form of nanoparticles, they are used as ferro-fluids [3] that have great applications in medicine. The most important applications of these ferro-fluids are in resonance magnetic imaging [4], hyperthermia [5], and especially targeting drug delivery [6]. Nanoparticles of ferrites have shown two important effects: the first consists of surface spin canting caused by broken bonds at the surface, which has been mentioned by several groups working experimentally on RFe2O4 (R=Co,Zn, and Ni) [7–9].

The second effect is attributed to a distribution of superexchange interactions and cations in the nanoparticles. A theoretical model for NiFe2O4 nanoparticles was proposed by Kodama et al. [10] and later generalized for the spinel ferrites [11]. An interesting behavior was observed in nanoparticles of (Mn,Zn)Fe2O4 [12] and NiFe2O4 [9]. These nanoparticles showed a superparamagnetic behavior after annealing the sample. This phenomenon was interpreted as being due to a redistribution of cations.

The spinel crystal structure AB2O4 is a close-packed face-centered cubic oxygen lattice with cations in the interstitial tetrahedral and octahedral sites. The unit cell contains 32 oxygen anions and 24 cations, 8 of which are distributed in the 64 tetrahedral sites (A-sites), and 16 in the 32 octahedral sites (B-sites). Each B-site ion has six nearest oxygen neighbors while each A-site ion has four nearest oxygen neighbors. It has been reported that the distance between the ions and their nearest neighbors is the smallest for the B–B neighbors and A–B neighbors, and the largest separation is between the A–A neighbors [13].

One can distinguish three different spinel types: the “normal,” the “inverse,” and the “mixed” spinel structures. In the case of the normal spinel, the trivalent cations are placed only on the B-sites, while the divalent cations are positioned on the A-sites. In the case of the inverse spinel, half of the B-sites are occupied by the divalent ions and the trivalent ions occupy half of the B-sites and the A-sites. A theoretical calculation was conducted for the purpose of how the trivalent cations and divalent cations distribute over the A-sites and B-sites [14].

The study takes into account crystal field splitting and also geometrical considerations. The authors have given quantitative values for the stabilization energy ΔE of the spinel unit cell, which is the difference of energy between the normal case and the inverse case of the spinel structure [14]. ΔE vary from some hundreds of meV to more than 1 eV. When ΔE is small, a mixed inverse/normal structure can occur. For the normal case, the Fe3+ ions prefer occupation of the octahedral sites; however, when other cations have a stronger B-site preference, an inverse spinel structure appears.

Section1.Heading: Experiments and results
Section1.Para: MnFe2O4 nanoparticles were prepared by a modified co-precipitation chemical technique [15]. The MnFe2O4 nanopowders were formed by dissolving 0.1 M of FeCl3⋅6H2O (99 %, Merck) with 0.05 M of MnCl2⋅4H2O (99 %, Merck) in deionized water at a ratio of [Fe3+]/[Mn2+]=2:1 to maintain the stoichiometry of the spinel ferrite. The 3 M solution of NaOH slowly was added into the mixed metal chloride precursor solution until the pH reached 13.5. The obtained black mixture was heated under the reflux process in the 100 °C for 1 h. The resulting precipitation was filtered, repeatedly washed with deionized water and dried at 60 °C under 200 mbar (in air) for 24.

The crystal structure of the powder sample was investigated by X-Ray diffractometer at 40 kV/30 mA with CuKα radiation (λ=1.540560 Å). Size and shape of nanoparticles were determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Philips CM30). In order to determine the crystalline structure, selected area electron diffraction (SAED) was carried out on the samples. The study of the magnetic properties was performed with a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) at the Magnetic Laboratory of “Ecole Polytechnique de Montréal,” Montreal, Canada.

A typical X-Ray powder diffraction spectra of Mn ferrite nanoparticles is shown in Fig. 1. This figure exhibits a polycrystalline structure of particles, which correspond to the spinel feature. The crystalline size using the Scherrer’s formula [16] was about 10 nm for these particles.
Fig. 1
XRD pattern of MnFe2O4 nanoparticles

The SEAD pattern in Fig. 2a corresponds to a cubic spinel structure. TEM image of MnFe2O4 particles that is demonstrated in Fig. 2b indicates a distribution of nearly spherical nanoparticles with different volumes. The average size was estimated as 30 nm.
Fig. 2
(a) SAED pattern, (b) TEM image of MnFe2O4 nanoparticles
Fig. 3
Histogram of particle size distribution obtained from sampling of nanoparticles from TEM micrograph of MnFe2O4

Magnetization versus temperature was investigated under Field Cooled (FC) condition. The sample cooled from room temperature to T=140 in a magnetic field of 22 kOe. At T=140 K, the magnetic field was set to 22 kOe and the magnetization measurements were performed at T=140 K. Starting from T=140 K to 400 K, we performed a magnetization measurement. We applied a single magnetic field pulse (H 0) between two consecutive measurements. Under these conditions and for different values of the applied magnetic field pulse (H 0=0, 100, 200, and 500 Oe), a pronounced anomaly was observed at T=324 K, as shown in Fig. 4. We conjecture that this anomaly might be attributed to further oxidation of Mn ions from Mn2+ to Mn3+ or Mn4+ and, subsequently, appearance of the Jahn–Teller distortion. This oxidation process might cause some defects in the MnFe2O4 structure [17, 20].
Fig. 4
The FC magnetization of MnFe2O4 nanoparticles at different applied magnetic field

Figure 5 shows the magnetization behavior of the MnFe2O4 sample. Figures 5a and 5b correspond to the M–H curves of the nanoparticles at T=300 and 450 K, respectively. In Fig. 5a, there is a standard hysteresis loop of magnetization; however, there is a remarkable opening up of the loop at higher temperature as can be observed in Fig. 5b. Note that this different behavior takes place at opposite sides of anomaly at 324 K in Fig. 4. Such opening up has been reported before in CoFe2O4 nanoparticles at T=300 K [18].
Fig. 5
Magnetization curve of MnFe2O4 nanoparticles at (a) T=300 K and (b) T=450 K (t=60 min)

The opening up of the M–H curve of Mn ferrite observed in Fig. 5b may be attributed to the oxidation state of Mn ions. Multiple oxidation states are supposed to exist for Mn ions in the chemical structure of MnFe2O4 [19]. The increase of the valence of Mn ions from +2 to +3 can reduce the magnetization [20]; therefore, the decreased magnetization in the back route would be due to the conversion of a large number of Mn2+ to Mn3+. In this condition, there is the Jahn–Teller distortion of the Mn3+ ion environment, and consequently, an enhanced crystal anisotropy, exchange interaction, and inversion parameter (i.e., percentage of Mn ions on octahedral sites) [17, 20].

Less reduction of magnetization was observed when the temperature is increased to 460 K (see Fig. 6). This could be due to an increasing percentage of Mn2+ relative to Mn3+ in the structure. The heat treatment can change the distribution of cations and their oxidation states, thus an increase in the temperature may cause the Mn3+ ions to reduce to Mn2+. The change of the Mn oxidation state is then due to the loss of oxygen anions in the heated nanoparticles [19].
Fig. 6
Magnetization curve of MnFe2O4 nanoparticles at T=460 K (t=60 min)

The time of application of the applied field was one hour for the magnetization curve in Figs. 5 and 6. In order to investigation the effect of time on the magnetization behavior, the application time of the applied field was increased to 70 min. As shown in Fig. 7, the reduction of magnetization in the back route (for positive field) vanished. This phenomenon might be due to the complete conversion of Mn3+ to Mn2+ in the structure of the nanoparticles under the influence of prolonged heat treatment at +5000 Oe. We think that the variation of the oxidation states of Mn ions in the MnFe2O4 structure with temperature and annealing time plays an important role in the magnetic property changes, as was also concluded in [17].
Fig. 7
Magnetization curve of MnFe2O4 for t=70 min, (a) T=450 K, (b) T=460 K

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: MnFe2O4 nanoparticles with interesting behavior in the magnetization curve were prepared by a coprecipitation method. For the first time, an opening up was observed in M–H curve at T=450 K, while this phenomenon gradually vanished with increasing temperature and time of application of the applied field. Therefore, temperature and time of application of the magnetic field is expected to play an important role in the M−H curve behavior.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgements
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: The authors appreciate Professor Arthur Yelon for his valuable comments and kind guidance. Also, we appreciate Professor David Menard for his support and we thank the Magnetic Laboratory of “Ecole Polytechnique de Montréal,” Department of Physics Engineering, Montreal, Canada, in which we carried out our magnetic measurements.
